title: Can you help me identify this classical music piece (details of the song in a comment I left below)? - Quora

response.answer_text: I first wrote: Since you’ve attached no sound clip, my best guess is that it is 4′33″ by John Cage. But since then the question-asker has commented, and clarified: The piece was definitely in a minor key. By my basic classical music knowledge, I’m guessing it was by a Russian composer from the 19th or 20th century. The song’s striking feature was that it starts with a sudden dense chord in the bass, followed by a really cool three- or four-octave arpeggio that went from the bass, up the keyboard and back down again. It rings a bell with me - in fact I’m almost certain I can hear a piece that matches the description in my head! - but I can’t place it instantly. Can anyone else help?

A few contenders come to mind: Chopin, Ballade No. 1 in G minor, Op. 23 Chopin, Études Op. 10 and Op. 25 (click through all 24) Scriabin, Piano Sonata No. 1, Op. 6 Liszt, Études d'exécution transcendante, S.139 (click through all twelve) It’s hard to suggest anything more specific with the limited information provided. You might have some luck going through the ouevres of Russian composers (if you are certain it was Russian) on YouTube (many videos amalgamate a large number of pieces together) and testing each one. Otherwise, could you reach out to the pianist and ask what the piece was? Or perhaps someone else who was there with you at the time?

When you say it was “a song” do you mean it was sung by a soloist? Do you remember if it was sung by a male or female voice? Can you describe the overall mood of the piece - sad, lament, angry, joyous, slow, fast, dramatic, serious, comic… and about how long? 1 or 2 minutes? 8 or 9 minutes? If it was sung, do you recall if it was in Russian, German, or any other language you recognized? Did it have any kind of descriptive title? Was it for piano only - a piano recital piece?

Thanks for the A2A. How about this?  Actually it starts with the horn arpeggios and orchestral tutti, but when you said “dense chords in the piano” I thought you might recall the piano part, but not the horns before it. If I got it wrong, sorry.
